text: @AuerbachKeller I've read a couple of essays like Mind-Body and Body-mind but not this one. Thanks for suggesting.
@NegarestaniReza Have you read Benny Shanon's The Antipodes of the Mind? Very influential on how I view this. https://t.co/OzxygjcFkL
@AuerbachKeller Neuroscience has shed great light on how and why we have been working with pre-packaged structured data.

@AuerbachKeller Those data structures being more explicit & specified in the case of AI isn't necessarily an argument against it in favor of bio-systems. We have great knowledge at this point that our sensory data structuration can be the same but we couldn't see it as such for a very long time.

@NegarestaniReza A little myth of the given here. One of the main problems of AI is an inability to regiment raw inputs in the ways humans/animals are predisposed to. The ways in which they *do* regiment data are more specified & explicit...though that's changing.
As in aphasia and other neurological disorders which show the absence of pre-structured input data for the biological organisms as opposed to AI systems is just a myth.

The bottom line of this: Why should we assume only artificial systems work with structured data & not the biological systems, knowing for a fact that if we change the parameters of sensors-effectors correlations, we fundamentally get different sort of results for biological sys.
Such that if this structured data is lost or compromised, such biological-cognitive systems start to become extremely erratic.

And if not more, then at least a similar level. So why then we think AI systems are in principle less natural than biological systems. Looking at different types of aphasia, we can see how profoundly biological systems work with structured data.

One of my arguments against positions that hold AI systems--but not biological neural systems--always work with pre-structured data is that to point out that every sort of sensory-effector correlation in biological systems actually imposes more structure on data than AI stuff.
